Short options:
  -D name[=value]		Define a symbol

  -d				Debug mode
  -g				Add debug info to object file
  -h				Help (this text)
  -i				Ignore case of symbols

  -mm model			Set the memory model
  -o name			Name the output file
  -s				Enable smart mode
  -S				Enable segment offset listing
  -t sys			Set the target system
  -v				Increase verbosity
  -x				Expand macros

--help.stdout:
Usage: C:/Users/dell/Documents/projeler/d64_converter/disaridan kullanilacak ornek programlar/c64 compiler/dreamass/dreamass.exe [OPTION | FILE]...
A crossassembler for 6510, 65816 and compatible CPUs.

Options:
  -d,  --debug <FILENAME>       write debug output to <FILENAME>.
                                default is no debug output.
  -D<VAR>=<VAL>                 define variable <VAR> with value <VAL>.
  -e,  --error-log <FILENAME>   log all errors to <FILENAME>.
                                default is no errorlogging.
  -h,  --help                   display this help and exit.
  -I<PATH>                      add <PATH> to include paths.
  -l,  --label-log <FILENAME>   write all labels with their value to <FILENAME>.
                                default is no label log.
  -me, --max-errors <NUMBER>    stop after <NUMBER> errors, 0 means endless.
                                default is 20.
  -mw, --max-warnings <NUMBER>  stop after <NUMBER> warnings, 0 means endless.
                                default is 20.
  -o,  --output <FILENAME>      write output to <FILENAME>.
                                default is a.out .
  -r,  --simple-redefine        allow simple redefines.
                                default is off.
  -v,  --verbose                be verbose.
                                default is verbose off.
       --version                display version information and exit.
  -W<TAG>                       modify warning level.

Non-option arguments are filenames of assembler sources. They are searched
in the directory where dreamass was invoked from. If this fails, all include
paths are searched in the order of their appearance on the comandline.
Files included from within the assembler source are searched the same way.

  dreamass main.src                             assemble main.src to a.out
  dreamass -o main.prg main.src                 assemble main.src to main.prg
  dreamass -Dcars=20 race.src                   define cars=20 and assemble race.src
  dreamass -DData="names.db" addressbook.src    define Data="names.db" and assemble addressbook.src

	Specify number of cycles to run before quitting with an error.

--help.stdout:
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                C64List (v3.03) Copyright 2012 by Jeff Hoag
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 Loads Commodore 64 BASIC programs and converts them between various formats.
 Contact: c64List@gmail.com
 Automatically determines the format to load by the file extension.
 Loads these file types
   prg  (prg C64 format: 2 address bytes followed by program data
   p00  (same as prg, but contains filename data as well)
   txt  (prg/p00 files detokenized and converted to text by C64List
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Syntax:
	c64list <input filename> [control parameters]

where control parameters include:
	-ovr  		overwrite an existing file
	-prg[:name]	save in .prg format
	-p00[:name]	save in .p00 format (Only p00 is supported--not 01-99)
	-hex[:name]	save in an ASCII hex dump format
	-asm[:name]	save in a memory-disassembled format
	-txt[:name]	save untokenized BASIC code in a text format
	-lbl[:name]	save, same as -txt, except convert to label format

	-verbose[:list]	output additional information during conversion
	-tokenizer:name	load a tokenizer map file
	-b4		load the BASIC 4.0 tokenizer map file
	-b7		load the BASIC 7.0 tokenizer map file
	-alpha:<mode>	where <mode> can be normal|upper|lower|invert
	-range:n1-n2	for .hex/.asm, only output indicated range
	-con		for .hex/.asm, dump output to screen
	-sym		dump the asm symbol table to screen
	-labels		dump the list of labels to screen

Additionally, when converting to and from text files:
	-crunch	(from text) removes unquoted space
	-crunch	(to text) adds spacing for readability
	-crsr	(to text) preserves binary cursor codes
	-rem	remove all REM statements

For the output format parameters, if you specify
  <nothing> the input name is used, but the proper extension is applied
  :<name> the specified name is used

-h.stdout:
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                C64List (v3.03) Copyright 2012 by Jeff Hoag
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 Loads Commodore 64 BASIC programs and converts them between various formats.
 Contact: c64List@gmail.com
 Automatically determines the format to load by the file extension.
 Loads these file types
   prg  (prg C64 format: 2 address bytes followed by program data
   p00  (same as prg, but contains filename data as well)
   txt  (prg/p00 files detokenized and converted to text by C64List
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Syntax:
	c64list <input filename> [control parameters]

where control parameters include:
	-ovr  		overwrite an existing file
	-prg[:name]	save in .prg format
	-p00[:name]	save in .p00 format (Only p00 is supported--not 01-99)
	-hex[:name]	save in an ASCII hex dump format
	-asm[:name]	save in a memory-disassembled format
	-txt[:name]	save untokenized BASIC code in a text format
	-lbl[:name]	save, same as -txt, except convert to label format

	-verbose[:list]	output additional information during conversion
	-tokenizer:name	load a tokenizer map file
	-b4		load the BASIC 4.0 tokenizer map file
	-b7		load the BASIC 7.0 tokenizer map file
	-alpha:<mode>	where <mode> can be normal|upper|lower|invert
	-range:n1-n2	for .hex/.asm, only output indicated range
	-con		for .hex/.asm, dump output to screen
	-sym		dump the asm symbol table to screen
	-labels		dump the list of labels to screen

Additionally, when converting to and from text files:
	-crunch	(from text) removes unquoted space
	-crunch	(to text) adds spacing for readability
	-crsr	(to text) preserves binary cursor codes
	-rem	remove all REM statements

For the output format parameters, if you specify
  <nothing> the input name is used, but the proper extension is applied
  :<name> the specified name is used

--help.stdout:
Call with C64Ass [options] [file]

-H, --HELP                     - Display this help
-O, --OUTFILE [Filename]       - Determine output file name
-L, --LABELDUMP [Filename]     - Write a label file
-LIB, --LIBRARY [Library Path] - Add path(s) to library paths
                                 Multiple paths are separated by comma
-F, --FORMAT [PLAIN/CBM]       - Sets the output file format
                                 PLAIN is a raw binary, CBM a .prg file
--SETPC [Address]              - Overrides the source start address
-AUTOTRUNCATELITERALS          - Clamps literal values to bytes/words without error
-D, --DEFINE [Key=Value]       - Add Predefines
-N, --NOWARNINGS               - Show no warnings
-I, --IGNORE [WarningNo]       - Ignore specific Warnings
                                 Multiple warnings separated by comma
-V, --VERSION                  - Display version
-A, --ASSEMBLER [Assembler]    - Use [Assembler]'s syntax
                                 Valid values are
                                 C64STUDIO (default)
                                 ACME
                                 C64ASM
                                 CBMPRGSTUDIO
                                 DASM
                                 KICKASSEMBLER
                                 PDS
                                 TASM

--help.stdout:
c6510 version 1.0.0 - a macro based cross-assembler for C64
  Originally written by CRT a.k.a. John Hammarberg
  Extended by Krikkit a.k.a. Robert Lundquist
Usage: c6510 [OPTIONS...] FILES...
Example: c6510 -s output.prg - + input.s
Options:
  -h, --help                              This help text
  -i, --input <file>                      Add source file to assemble
  -p, --path <path>                       Add a search path for includes
  -d, --declare <name>[=<value>]          Define constant 'name', with optional value, before any files are assembled
  -s, --save <file> <start> <end>         Save a block of memory after assembly in PRG format. Labels can be used as addresses
  -f, --freeze <src file> <dst file>      Update a VICE compatible freeze image with assembled content
  -y, --sym <file>                        Dump a symbol file in VICE format
  -wo, --warn-overwrite                   Only warn when overwriting already defined memory (default treat as error)
  -b, --build-file <file>                 Save build file with include paths
